tit.cmt: （）内は三省堂・大辞林「兵粮料所」項目の一部を訳出したもの。
tit.e: Hyoro-ryosho (grant areas for the support of troops in the field)

sen.j: 兵粮料所（ひょうろうりょうしょ）とは、中世において兵粮米を徴収するために指定された特定の所領のこと。
sen.e: Hyoro-Ryosho were areas of land set aside during the medieval period and devoted to producing rations and provisions (specifically, rice) for soldiers.
Hyoro-Ryosho were areas of land set aside during the medieval period and devoted to producing rations and provisions (specifically, rice) for soldiers.
Hyoro-ryosho were areas of land set aside during the medieval period and devoted to producing rations and provisions (specifically, rice) for soldiers.

sen.j: 律令制下の蝦夷討伐においで東国諸国の正税を遠征軍の兵粮にあてる事を許した。
sen.e: During the military campaigns, launched under and during the ritsuryo system (roughly corresponding to the Heian period), to subjugate the Ezo (or Ebisu) barbarian peoples of northeastern Japan, the various eastern provinces were permitted to pay their taxes (of rice) in the form of supplying the expeditionary troops with provisions.
sen.cmt: （）内は研究社・新和英大辞典「律令制」項目の引用。 Note that my parenthetical remark is I think important to explain to non-specialists what period is under discussion here.
sen.e: During the military campaigns, launched under and during the ritsuryo system (roughly corresponding to the Heian period), to subjugate the Ezo (or Ebisu) barbarian peoples of northeastern Japan, the various eastern provinces were permitted to pay their taxes (of rice) in the form of supplying the expeditionary troops with provisions.

During the military campaigns, launched under and during the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), to subjugate the Ezo (or Ebisu) barbarian peoples of northeastern Japan, the various eastern provinces were permitted to pay their taxes (of rice) in the form of supplying the expeditionary troops with provisions.

sen.j: 源平の戦いにおいて、河内源氏・平家双方が諸国より兵粮負担を求めた。
sen.e: During the Genpei War (the twelfth-century war between the Minamoto and Taira clans), the Kawachi Genji (a branch of the Minamoto clan) and the Taira family each tried to get various provinces to shoulder the burden of supplying their armies with provisions.

During the Genpei War (the twelfth-century war between the Minamoto and Taira clans), the Kawachi Genji (a branch of the Minamoto clan) and the Taira family each tried to get various provinces to shoulder the burden of supplying their armies with provisions.

During the Genpei War (the twelfth-century war between the Minamoto and Taira clans), the Kawachi Genji (the Minamoto clan) and the Taira family each asked various provinces to shoulder the burden of supplying their armies with provisions.
sen.cmt: a branch of the Minamoto clan→the Minamoto clantried to get→asked

sen.j: 文治元年（1185年）に源頼朝が守護・地頭の設置求めて文治の勅許を受けると、同時に荘園・国衙領の田1段から兵粮米5升を徴収する権利を得た。
sen.e: In 1185 (the first year of the Bunji era), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, seeking to establish a system of shugo and jito (governors and estate stewards), was granted the Bunji Imperial Sanction to do so, simultaneously obtaining the authority to collect five sho (measures) of rice, for the purpose of supplying troops, from each tan (section) of each rice paddy on shoen (private estates) and kokugaryo (public territories) alike.
sen.cmt: Note that I included the era name because of its connection to the Bunji Imperial Sanction.
sen.e: In 1185 (the first year of the Bunji era), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, seeking to establish a system of shugo and jito (governors and estate stewards), was granted the Bunji Imperial Sanction to do so, simultaneously obtaining the authority to collect five sho (measures) of rice, for the purpose of supplying troops, from each tan (section) of each rice paddy on shoen (private estates) and kokugaryo (public territories) alike.

In 1185 (the first year of the Bunji era), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, seeking to establish a system of Shugo (provincial constable) and jito (manager and lord of manor), was granted the Bunji Imperial Sanction to do so, simultaneously obtaining the authority to collect five sho (measures) of rice, for the purpose of supplying troops, from each tan (section) of each rice paddy on shoen (manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) alike.
sen.cmt: 守護・地頭、荘園、国衙領の定訳

sen.j: だが、国司・荘園領主達の反発が強く、翌年には撤回された。
sen.e: Resistance among provincial governors and the lords of shoen was fierce, however, so the following year this authority was revoked.
Resistance among provincial governors and the lords of shoen was fierce, however, so the following year this authority was revoked.
Resistance among provincial governors and the lords of shoen was fierce, however, so the following year this authority was revoked.

sen.j: 承久の乱後には鎌倉幕府が備前国・備中国両国より兵粮米を受け取る権利が認められた。
sen.e: After the Jokyu War, the authority of the Kamakura bakufu (shogunate) to collect provisions for the troops from both Bizen and Bicchu provinces was recognized.
After the Jokyu War, the authority of the Kamakura bakufu (shogunate) to collect provisions for the troops from both Bizen and Bicchu provinces was recognized.
After the Jokyu War, the authority of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to collect provisions for the troops from both Bizen and Bicchu provinces was recognized.

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)に入ると、北朝 (日本)を擁した室町幕府は、兵粮確保を名目に半済令を出して荘園・公領の年貢半分の徴収権を守護に認めた。
sen.e: Upon entering the Nanbokucho period, the Muromachi bakufu, which championed the Northern Court, issued the Half-Tax Law on the pretense of keeping the army provisioned; the law recognized the authority of the shugo (governors) to levy a half-tax (50% of all rice) annually on all private estates and public territories.

Upon entering the Nanbokucho period, the Muromachi bakufu, which championed the Northern Court, issued the Half-Tax Law on the pretense of keeping the army provisioned; the law recognized the authority of the shugo (governors) to levy a half-tax (50% of all rice) annually on all private estates and public territories.

Upon entering the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the Muromachi bakufu, which championed the Northern Court, issued Hanzeirei (order allowing military governors, or Shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund) on the pretense of keeping the army provisioned; the law recognized the authority of Shugo (provincial constable) to levy a half-tax (50% of all rice) annually on all private estates and public territories.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代、半済令、守護の定訳

sen.j: この半済令の対象地は兵粮料所と呼ばれて当初は激戦地の8ヶ国に限定されていたが、南朝 (日本)側がこれに対抗して朝用分制度を導入したこともあって次第に広がりを見せて全国的な半済へと至り、兵粮料所は事実上守護領に編入されることとなった。
sen.e: The territory to which this Half-Tax Law applied, or in other words the territory called hyoro-ryosho, was initially limited to the eight provinces involved in the fiercest fighting, but the Southen Court forces, to counter this move, introduced their own system of separating out a portion of rice for use by the court and its adherents, so that the half-tax system gradually spread until it eventually covered the entire country, until the hyoro-ryosho, the territories producing rice to supply the army, were in actuality absorbed into the territories of each shugo (governors).

The territory to which this Half-Tax Law applied, or in other words the territory called hyoro-ryosho, was initially limited to the eight provinces involved in the fiercest fighting, but the Southen Court forces, to counter this move, introduced their own system of separating out a portion of rice for use by the court and its adherents, so that the half-tax system gradually spread until it eventually covered the entire country, until the hyoro-ryosho, the territories producing rice to supply the army, were in actuality absorbed into the territories of each shugo (governors).

The territory to which this Hanzeirei applied, or in other words the territory called hyoro-ryosho, was initially limited to the eight provinces involved in the fiercest fighting, but the Southen Court, to counter this move, introduced their own system of separating out a portion of rice for use by the court and its adherents, so that Hanzeirei gradually spread until it eventually covered the entire country, until the hyoro-ryosho were in actuality absorbed into the territories of each shugo.
sen.cmt: Half-Tax Law→Hanzeireiforces→削除the territories producing rice to supply the army→既出の説明のため削除(governors)→削除
